messageBody:
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Chris Dollin

I don't understand why a hierarchical design requires that the *test
classes* be hierarchically organised.


That's a good observation, and I fully agree with it.

Having said that, there's still need for inheritance hierarchies to work on
tests, but there is no reason why it shouldn't obey the simple rule that if
you don't need something, you shouldn't extend the class that provides it.

My test hierarchies have a few levels of inheritance and include a mix of:

- Sharing utility methods that are not tests.

- Sharing tests that provide the same functionalities but initialized with
different parameters depending on which subclass they are in. In TestNG,
this is obtained either by passing different parameters to my test methods
or having TestNG invoke specific constructors with values configured in
testng.xml. I believe you can reach a similar result with a TestDecorator
in JUnit.
